Award.AwardTitle: Physical Impacts on late Season Productivity in Changing Arctic
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Arctic region is experiencing environmental changes that have important implications for the local Arctic ecosystem and the communities that depend on it for their subsistence. For example, a longer season of reduced ice cover suggests the possibility of more marine plant growth. Yet, the rate at which plants grow may be limited by the exhaustion of available nutrients during the longer growing season. Understanding is limited by an incomplete knowledge of how physical processes help replenish nutrients in the euphotic zone late in the season. Important processes span a range of scales, from small scale turbulent mixing to regional scale wind-driven upwelling. This project will pair novel physical and biological measurements to understand the biological response to changes in the physics. The work takes advantage of a scheduled cruise to reduce costs. The project will contribute to STEM workforce enhancement by supporting the development of an early career scientist. Public outreach will be accomplished through a science communication fellowship at the Oregon Museum of Science and Industry.

During a cruise to the Chukchi Sea in late summer, instruments to measure fine-scale shear, velocity, and turbulence will be integrated onto a towed vehicle capable of high-resolution sampling over broad areas. The towed vehicle, which is funded through an existing project, allows for continuous in-situ water sampling throughout the water column and is equipped with a suite of comprehensive biological sensors and standard physical sensors. The proposed additions will yield a unique set of simultaneous, comprehensive high-resolution physical and biological observations. The collective analysis of these observations will provide critical insight into biophysical interactions in the changing Arctic.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This work paired physical measurements of the ocean circulation with biogeochemical measurements of nutrients, phytoplankton, and water column composition to study how the ocean's "weather" impacts the ecosystem of the Chukchi Sea. This grant supported the addition of physical measurements to the previously funded biogeochemical measurements. The interpretation of the data was a collaborative effort. The intellectual merits of the completed work center around understanding of how storm-activity with associated wind-driven mixing and upwelling impact biological productivity and carbon cycling in the Chukchi Sea. In addition to demonstrating the strength of the integrated measurement approach, this work established a baseline for the Chukchi's biogeochemical-physical regime at very high spatial resolution (~100 m). Even at these small scales, the Chukchi exhibits significant changes in nutrients, water type, chlorophyll, and ocean mixing; and the structure of the ocean is heavily influenced by physical processes like wind-driven upwelling.  Upwelling modifies the nutrient distribution by raising deep, nutrient-rich water closer to the surface. Upwelling also changes the current system and can lead to a state which is unstable, resulting in stirring and mixing of different waters with different nutrient concentrations. Given that phytoplankton blooms are linked to the distribution of nutrient-rich water masses, the redistribution of nutrients by instabilities across fronts may have very strong control over the regional ecosystem.

 Understanding of the ocean's circulation on the ecosystem's lower trophic levels is the first step to understanding how the system will evolve under continued Arctic change. Arctic surface temperatures are warming at a rate two times greater than the global average. While the mechanisms leading to this trend are not easily isolated, many of its consequences are clear: sea ice extent is decreasing, the open water season is lengthening, and sea ice cover is transitioning toward thinner, younger ice cover. All of these factors lead to the potential for increased growth of phytoplankton in the Arctic known as "Arctic Greening", due to enhanced light levels as well as changes in the ocean's stratification (i.e., the changes in ocean density with depth). Increases in the production of phytoplankton will, in turn, affect higher trophic levels several culturally valued species, e.g., walrus, bowhead and gray whales, bearded seals. These changes also have implications to global climate through exchange of CO2 and heat with the atmosphere. Our results illustrated the value of, and need for further, coordinated physical / biogeochemical observations to understand their influence on the changing biogeochemistry of the Pacific Arctic. The motivation for and results from this work were shared via outreach efforts to the community (e.g., through the University of Alaska-Nome Public Talks and the Oregon Museum of Science and Industry Science Communication Fellowship).
